video.title: Intermediate React Tutorial - Todoist Clone (with Firebase, Custom Hooks, SCSS, React Testing)
video.description:
In this course, we're going to be creating the popular Todoist list application (https://todoist.com) from scratch using React (Custom Hooks, Context), Firebase & React Testing Library (unit & integration testing). In addition to the latter technologies, we will be styling the application using SCSS (CSS) and following the BEM naming methodology.

We'll make sure that the application is fully responsive. You will see how to use Lighthouse (Chrome extension) to make sure your website is fully accessible by getting all accessibility features integrated into our application.

💻 Github repo: https://github.com/karlhadwen/todoist (don't forget, you can contribute to this project (highly encouraged!))

🎥 Video by Karl Hadwen. Check out his YouTube channel: https://youtube.com/c/cognitivesurge
🐦 Karl on Twitter: @karlhadwen

topLevelComment.author: Mohammad Dehgamwala
topLevelComment.text:
Hey @karl Hadwen
There is a thing you've missed 

if you use -- useTasks('next_7')
you will not only get tasks of next 7 days but also previous days
because moment(task.date).diff(moment(), ''days') <= 7 will also check for negative numbers 
so to prevent it add another condition --

  moment(task.date).diff(moment(), ''days') <= 7 &&  moment(task.date).diff(moment(), ''days') >= 0 

Thanks

replies.author: Chi P
replies.text: When you return a function from useEffect it will call this every time the component is unmounted. Think of it like a clean up function. However, unmounting does not mean essentially that the component is removed. For example, you select a project and then another, it will unsubscribe from it and subsribe to the new one because it is real time. At least that's how I understood how firebase works.

I know this is pretty old, but I thought the same when starting out programming, why write tests if you can test your program manually?
But trust me it helps on the long run, what if you updated some functionality on your program but accidentally broke something else, with traditional manual testing you may not realize that, but with automated testing you can run one command and if all is green you're good to go.

replies.author: Karl Hadwen
replies.text: Hey, thanks for the comments! Mostly we run somewhat automated tests that can be run through a CI to make sure we haven't changed something that has broke our expectations of what the test should assert to. Even though we can manual test (which a tester usually does), having it run through a build pipeline to make sure we're testing our code is one of the strongest reasons for testing that I find :)

topLevelComment.author: K K
topLevelComment.text: Great tutorial! I watched and coded along for 2 hours and I have a question about Context. I thought that Context is used to get values from global state in any component without passing it via props. What is the point of using Context like you did with ProjectsContext, for exmaple? Can't you just import useProjects hook in your component and get projects like that, withous using Context at all?

replies.author: Karl Hadwen
replies.text: Hi Ange, yep I'd probably say I went a little overkill with Context here but I just wanted to show how it could be used. Normally how I'd used Context is where I need true global state, e.g. something like 'import { useStateValue } from './state';' - where I can manage global state and have a somewhat of a Redux state management but using Context instead, good spot though! You can definitely remove Context here, but it's not fully needed as you can just use hooks.
